title: Step-by-Step Guide: Installing Python and Running Your First Script on Windows
summary: Learn how to install Python on Windows, set up Visual Studio Code, write your first Python script, and run it from the terminal.

seo.description: Step-by-step guide for beginners on installing Python on Windows, setting up VS Code, writing a simple script, and running it from the terminal.

keywords: how to run Python in terminal

sections.title: Introduction
sections.content: This tutorial walks you through how to install Python on Windows, set up Visual Studio Code, and run your first Python script. It is designed for beginners who want a clean, step-by-step start with Python.

sections.title: Step 1: Install Python
sections.content: Start by downloading Python from the official Python website. Choose the Windows installer, make sure the option to add Python to PATH is checked, and follow the installation steps until completion.

sections.title: Step 2: Install Visual Studio Code
sections.content: Install Visual Studio Code, a popular code editor for writing Python. Download it from the official website, run the installer, and enable useful options like creating a desktop shortcut and adding VS Code to the context menu.

sections.title: Step 3: Create a New Python Script
sections.content: Open Visual Studio Code and create a new file. Save it with a `.py` extension, for example `hello.py`. This file will contain your first Python script.

sections.title: Step 4: Write and Save Your Script
sections.content:
Inside your new Python file, write a simple script such as:

```python
print("Hello, Python from Neetechs!")
```
Save the file before running it.

sections.title: Step 5: Run Your Script in the Terminal
sections.content:
Open the integrated terminal in VS Code (View → Terminal), navigate to the folder where your script is saved if needed, and run:

```bash
python hello.py
```
You should see the output printed in the terminal.

sections.title: Step 6: Understanding the Output
sections.content: When the script runs successfully, the text from your `print` statement appears in the terminal. If you see errors instead, read the message carefully—most issues come from typos, wrong file paths, or forgetting to save the file.

sections.title: Step 7: Working with Variables
sections.content:
Extend your script by adding variables. For example:

```python
name = "Jihad"
age = 28
print("Name:", name)
print("Age:", age)
```
Run the script again to see how variables store and display data.

sections.title: Step 8: Running the Script Again After Changes
sections.content: Each time you change your code, save the file and rerun the script in the terminal. This quick cycle of edit → save → run helps you learn and debug faster.

sections.title: Step 9: Using Different Data Types
sections.content:
Try using different data types such as strings, integers, and lists:

```python
message = "Welcome to Neetechs"
count = 3
items = ["Python", "VS Code", "Terminal"]
print(message)
print("Count:", count)
print("Items:", items)
```
This helps you get familiar with how Python handles different kinds of values.

sections.title: Step 10: Summary and Next Steps
sections.content: You have installed Python, set up VS Code, written a script, and run it from the terminal. From here, you can move on to variables, data types, control structures, and eventually full projects using Python.

sections.title: Conclusion
sections.content: You are now ready to continue your Python journey with Neetechs. Keep practicing, experiment with new scripts, and explore the next tutorials in the Python path for variables, data types, control structures, and more.
